docs.title: What is Black Mesa?
docs.text: Black Mesa is a moderation bot for advanced server owners who love configuration without compromising performance .

docs.title: Who's behind it?
docs.text:
Black Mesa was written in Rust by @damaredayo.

The web dashboard was written in JavaScript by @bartflk & @damaredayo.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
The Black Mesa API is a RESTful API that allows you to interact with the bot. It is used by the web dashboard and can be used by other applications.

The API uses semver, so you can expect breaking changes to be introduced in new versions.

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text: The Black Mesa API uses OAuth2 for authentication. You can find more information about the OAuth2 flow here.

docs.title: Headers
docs.text: • Authorization is the OAuth2 access token.

docs.title: API Reference
docs.text: All API requests are made to https://api.blackmesa.bot/v1/.

This works with user IDs and role IDs {} ❌ modules Modules A struct of modules and their configurations. N/A ❌

docs.title: Groups
docs.text:
Groups are a way to group permissions together. They are used to make it easier to manage permissions for users. You can assign a group to a user or role and then assign permissions to that group.

Groups have the lowest permission priority, any permissions set on a user or role will override the group permissions.

docs.title: Default Groups
docs.text:
The following groups are available by default:

Group Default Permissions Inherits From default guild - dj music default moderator moderation dj admin admin moderator

NOTE: You can not remove the default group, but you can change the permissions. Black Mesa will always use the default group if no other group is set.

docs.title: Permissions
docs.text: Black Mesa has its own permissions system based on nodes. Each command has a permission node (e.g. moderation.ban) which is granted to a specific level. If the user (or the group the user is in) is below this level, they do not have the permission and as such has no access to the feature the permission locks.

docs.title: Permission Nodes
docs.text:
Permission nodes are fairly simple, each node is a string separated by a .. Each subnode holds a higher priority than the previous node. For example, moderation.ban has a higher priority than moderation. As an example, if you were to set moderation to 50 and moderation.ban to 100, a user with permission level 50 would have access to all moderation commands, apart from ban.

Please note when you see a * in a default group, this means that there is no override set and therefore inherits the level of the parent group.

docs.title: moderation
docs.text: Node Description Default Group moderation.ban Allows the user to ban users. * moderation.kick Allows the user to kick users. * moderation.mute Allows the user to mute users. * moderation.removeself Allows the user to remove an infraction that they have made. * moderation.expireself Allows the user to expire an infraction that they have made. * moderation.search Allows the user to search infraction logs of other users. * moderation.softban Allows the user to softban users. * moderation.strike Allows the user to strike users. * moderation.unban Allows the user to unban users. * moderation.unmute Allows the user to unmute users. * moderation.updateself Allows the user to update an infraction that they have made. *

docs.title: admin
docs.text: Node Description Default Level admin.makemute Allow the user to make a muted role. 101 admin.setup Allow the user to reset Black Mesa and run setup again. 101 admin.remove Allow the user to remove infractions from anyone. * admin.expire Allow the user to expire infractions from anyone. * admin.update Allow the user to update infractions from anyone. * admin.purge Allow the user to purge messages from a channel. *

docs.title: guild
docs.text: Node Description Default Level guild.userinfo Allow the user to view the general user information of a user. * guild.userinfoself Allow the user to view the general user information of themselves only. * guild.guildinfo Allow the user to view the general guild information. * guild.searchself Allow the user to view their own infractions. *

docs.title: roles
docs.text: Node Description Default Level roles.add Allow the user to add roles to users. * roles.remove Allow the user to remove roles from users. * roles.create Allow the user to create roles. * roles.rmrole Allow the user to delete roles. * roles.update Allow the user to update roles. * roles.list Allow the user to list roles. *

docs.title: music
docs.text: Node Description Default Level music.play Allow the user to play music. 0 music.stop Allow the user to stop music. * music.skip Allow the user to skip music. * music.remove Allow the user to remove music from the queue. * music.dc Allow the user to disconnect the bot from the channel. 50 music.seek Allow the user to seek the currently playing song. * music.volume Allow the user to adjust the volume of the currently playing song. 50

docs.title: Deep Search
docs.text: Deep Search the infractions from a target. This shows all infractions, including those that have expired.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
deepsearch [target:user]

If target is not specified, the command author is used.

docs.title: Required Permission
docs.text:
admin.deepsearch & moderation.search

OR

guild.searchself if target is the command author, the user has implied access to their expired infractions.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: • !deepsearch 96269247411400704

docs.title: Purge
docs.text: Purge messages messages from the current channel that match type and filter.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text: purge [type:string] [filter:string...] [messages:number]

docs.title: Permission
docs.text: admin.purge

docs.title: Filter types
docs.text:
• bots - Only messages from bots
  • string - Only messages that contain the specified string at filter
  • users - Only messages from users
  • all - All messages

docs.title: Assumptions / Shortcuts
docs.text:
• If type is not specified, all is assumed.

  • If type is specified as an ID, the bot will assume its type based on what the ID is for. (For example, if the ID is for a user, the bot will assume users and the ID will be added to filter.)

  • If messages looks like a user ID, the bot will assume it is a user and add it to filter.

  • If messages is not specified, 100 is assumed.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
• !purge 20 - Purge 20 messages from the current channel.
  • !purge bots 20 - Purge 20 messages from the current channel that are from bots.
  • !purge string naughty 20 - Purge 50 messages from the current channel that contain the word naughty.

docs.title: Argument Types
docs.text:
In command documentation, you've probably seen one of these:

  • <reason:string...>
  • <target:user[]>
  • [time:duration]

These are argument types. They are a way for users to identify what type is required for a certain argument when giving them a value. These are purely a documentation visualisation rather than something used by the bot itself.

As a quick breakdown, this is what each part means (in this case, <reason:string...>):

  • < and > are the requirements.
  • reason is the name of the argument.
  • : is a separator between the name and the type.
  • string is the type of the argument.
  • ... is a type modifier.

docs.title: Argument Requirements
docs.text: Arguments are surrounded by either [] or <>. These show the requirement level of the argument. Optional arguments are surrounded by [] and required arguments are surrounded by <>.

docs.title: Optional Argument Defaults
docs.text: Some optional arguments will have their default value in parentheses at the end of the string (e.g., [amount:number(1)]).

docs.title: Type Modifiers
docs.text: Type modifiers change the way a type is interpreted, including taking multiple of the same type as one argument.

docs.title: Array Types ([])
docs.text: Array types are a modifier that show that an argument can take multiple of the same type.

docs.title: Greedy Types (...)
docs.text: Greedy types are a modifier that is only used at the end of an argument list and is always used with strings that take the rest of the input and turn it into one argument.

docs.title: Or Types (|)
docs.text: Or types are a modifier that show that an argument can take multiple types. This is usually used for commands that target discord entities (e.g., users, roles, channels, etc.).

docs.title: Types
docs.text:
In command documentation, you've probably seen one of these:

  • string
  • user
  • duration

These are types. They are a way for users to identify what type is required for a certain command.

docs.title: Type List
docs.text: Type Description string A string of text. number A number. snowflake A snowflake. mention A mention. uuid A Unique Identifier. duration A duration. user A user. role A role. channel A channel. punishment A Punishment.

docs.title: string
docs.text: A string of text, typically used for a reason or a filter.

docs.title: number
docs.text: A number, typically used for an amount of something. NOT a duration.

docs.title: snowflake
docs.text:
A snowflake, typically used for a Discord ID.

An example of a valid snowflake is 96269247411400704.

More info can be found here: https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes

docs.title: mention
docs.text: A mention, any form of mention in discord is valid. This could look like @Tyler or #real-channel in your chat.

docs.title: uuid
docs.text:
A Unique Identifier, this is a unique identifier that is generated by Black Mesa. All infractions have a UUID, and this is how you can reference them.

An example of a UUID is c488c9ec-423a-437c-817c-41d0d4141e58.

If you are looking for an infraction, look to the search command.

docs.title: duration
docs.text:
A duration, Black Mesa has an intuitive duration parser that can parse any combination of the following units:

  • y for years
  • mo for months
  • w for weeks
  • d for days
  • h for hours
  • m for minutes
  • s for seconds

All units are optional, and the parser will default to seconds if no unit is provided. An example of a valid duration is 5d12h, which means 5 Days and 12 Hours will pass.

docs.title: user
docs.text: A Discord User. This can be a mention or a snowflake.

docs.title: role
docs.text: A Discord Role. This can be a mention or a snowflake.

docs.title: channel
docs.text: A Discord Channel. This can be a mention or a snowflake.

docs.title: punishment
docs.text:
A punishment, this is a punishment that can be applied to a user. This can be one of the following:

  • mute
  • strike
  • kick
  • ban
  • none
